results.title: The What did you think of the movie movie
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Kagan and American Film Institute
results.brief_description: This delightful satire of movie criticism covers the complete range of responses to the question in its title. In the most hilarious scenes, some of the “critics” warm up to their task and get carried away by their reactions to life on the silver screen.

results.title: The Whales are waiting
results.creator_credit: Andy Thomson, Strowan Robertson, Tony Ianzelo, Bill Brind and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Discusses the organisation called Project Jonah, which is committed to bringing about a moratorium on the killing of whales. Executive producer, Colin Law; editor, Marion Meadows.

results.title: The Wet fly man's dream
results.creator_credit: Gordon Glenn, Kent Chadwick and Film Victoria
results.brief_description: Looks at the factors, due to the activities of man, which have depleted the population of several species of native fish in the Murray-Darling river system. Examines some of the work of the Ministry of Conservation’s Fisheries and Wildlife Division aimed at saving these species from extinction. Also attempts to promote native fish species as game fish.

results.title: The Westward movement. Part 5. The Gold rush
results.creator_credit: Stanley Croner, John W Caughey and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: The 1840 Gold Rushes brought a flood of hardy adventurers to California; people of different races, nationalities, professions, and trades who dramatically advanced the settlement of the west; transformed San Francisco into a metropolis, and provided a great stimulus to commerce in the United States.

results.title: The Western tradition
results.creator_credit: Metropolitan Museum of Art and WGBH Educational Foundation
results.brief_description: An absorbing survey of more than 2,000 years of Western civilisation giving students an educational foundation that will serve through college and beyond and providing adults with a chance to discover the history that has shaped our modern world. This encyclopaedic series is illustrated with over 2,700 paintings, sculptures and other records of the past compiled by the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Eloquent historian Eugen Weber guides the viewer through centuries of politics, literature, economics, industry, agriculture, art, philosophy and the daily lives of ordinary people.

results.title: The Western garden
results.creator_credit: Luc Weber, Philippe Guerdat and Libraprim S A
results.brief_description: This documentary examines the history of gardens in the Western world, exploring their various functions over the centuries and how their constant state of change reflects the societies that revolve around them. Gardens - literally, pieces of land removed from their natural environments - have existed as sites of refuge, worship and meditation, served as accessories to political power, and provided humans with new ways of expressing art. From the cloistered medicinal gardens of medieval Europe to modern open parklands enclosed by cityscapes, gardens document “as much of the spirit of a period as its literature, its paintings or its sculpture”. Some of the stunning gardens explored in more detail include those at Villandry (France), Vaux-le-Vicomte (France), Hadrian’s Villa (Tivoli, Italy), Villa Garzoni (Collodi, Italy) Queen Eleanor’s Garden (Hampshire, UK), Hampton Court Palace (Surrey, UK), and the Royal Botanic Gardens (Kew, UK).

results.title: The West Indies: Caribbean region 1
results.brief_description: Historical overview of the West Indies. Shows the principal West Indies Islands, their strategic and economic value to the western world, their topography, climate, industries, and the peoples who live there today.

results.title: The Well of the saints
results.creator_credit: Larry Yust and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: A traditional Irish folk drama by John M. Synge, set in the east of Ireland, two or three centuries ago. The satiric theme - that sometimes it is better to preserve one’s illusions than to face reality - is expressed through the episode of Martin and Mary Doul’s miraculously restored sight. Part of the “Short play showcase” series.
